title: Orval Grove
original:
Orval Leroy Grove (August 29, 1919 – April 20, 1992) was an American professional baseball pitcher in Major League Baseball who played for ten seasons in the American League with the Chicago White Sox. In 207 career games, Grove pitched 1,176 innings and posted a win–loss record of 63–73, with 66 complete games, 11 shutouts, and a 3.78 earned run average (ERA).
The only freshman on the Proviso Township High School varsity baseball team, Grove's pitching ability attracted the attention of the White Sox. After signing with the team in 1937, Grove moved between the major leagues and minor leagues for a few seasons until 1943, when he found a solid place in the White Sox's pitching rotation. Grove had a career-year in 1943, finishing the season with career-bests in ERA, wins, and complete games; in 1944, he made his only All-Star appearance.
Grove spent four more full seasons with the White Sox, and after pitching one game in 1949, was sent to the Sacramento Solons of the Pacific Coast League. After playing four seasons with them, he formally retired from professional baseball. After retirement, he worked with his uncle in a trucking business in Chicago while continuing to pitch at the semi-pro level. In 1992, Grove died at the age of 72.
simplified:
Orval Leroy Grove was a baseball pitcher who played for the Chicago White Sox in the American League for ten years, from 1940 to 1949. During his career, he played in 207 games, pitched for 1,176 innings, and had 63 wins and 73 losses. He completed 66 games, had 11 shutouts, and his earned run average (ERA) was 3.78.

Grove started playing baseball in high school, where he was the only first-year student on the team. The White Sox noticed his talent and signed him in 1937. For a few years, he moved back and forth between the major and minor leagues. In 1943, he became a regular pitcher for the White Sox. That year was his best, with his highest number of wins and complete games, and his lowest ERA. In 1944, he was chosen for the All-Star game.

Grove played four more full seasons with the White Sox. After pitching one game in 1949, he was sent to play for a minor league team called the Sacramento Solons. He played there for four years before retiring from professional baseball. After retiring, Grove worked in his uncle's trucking business in Chicago and continued to pitch in semi-professional games. He died in 1992 at the age of 72.

title: Orval Grove
original:
Orval Leroy Grove (August 29, 1919 – April 20, 1992) was an American professional baseball pitcher in Major League Baseball who played for ten seasons in the American League with the Chicago White Sox. In 207 career games, Grove pitched 1,176 innings and posted a win–loss record of 63–73, with 66 complete games, 11 shutouts, and a 3.78 earned run average (ERA).
The only freshman on the Proviso Township High School varsity baseball team, Grove's pitching ability attracted the attention of the White Sox. After signing with the team in 1937, Grove moved between the major leagues and minor leagues for a few seasons until 1943, when he found a solid place in the White Sox's pitching rotation. Grove had a career-year in 1943, finishing the season with career-bests in ERA, wins, and complete games; in 1944, he made his only All-Star appearance.
Grove spent four more full seasons with the White Sox, and after pitching one game in 1949, was sent to the Sacramento Solons of the Pacific Coast League. After playing four seasons with them, he formally retired from professional baseball. After retirement, he worked with his uncle in a trucking business in Chicago while continuing to pitch at the semi-pro level. In 1992, Grove died at the age of 72.
simplified:
Orval Leroy Grove (August 29, 1919 – April 20, 1992) was an American baseball pitcher who played in Major League Baseball. He played for ten years with the Chicago White Sox in the American League. Over his career, Grove played in 207 games and pitched 1,176 innings. He had 63 wins and 73 losses, with 66 complete games, 11 shutouts, and a 3.78 ERA (earned run average).

Grove was the only freshman on his high school baseball team, and his pitching skills caught the attention of the White Sox. He signed with them in 1937 and spent a few years going between the major leagues and minor leagues. In 1943, he became a steady part of the White Sox's pitching team. That year, he performed his best with his lowest ERA, most wins, and most complete games. In 1944, he made his only appearance in the All-Star game.

Grove played four more full seasons with the White Sox. After pitching one game in 1949, he was sent to the Sacramento Solons, a team in the Pacific Coast League. He played with them for four seasons before retiring from professional baseball. After retiring, he worked with his uncle's trucking business in Chicago and continued to play semi-pro baseball. Grove passed away in 1992 at the age of 72.

simplicity_issues.original_span: Grove had a career-year in 1943, finishing the season with career-bests in ERA, wins, and complete games
simplicity_issues.simplified_span: In 1943, he became a steady part of the White Sox's pitching team. That year, he performed his best with his lowest ERA, most wins, and most complete games.
simplicity_issues.explanation: The simplified text suggests that Grove's performance in 1943 was due to becoming a steady part of the team, which is not explicitly stated in the original. The original text emphasizes that 1943 was a career-best year for Grove, but does not directly link this to his steadiness in the team.
simplicity_issues.suggested_fix: Revise to: 'In 1943, he had a career-best year with his lowest ERA, most wins, and most complete games, solidifying his role in the White Sox's pitching team.'

simplicity_issues.original_span: After retirement, he worked with his uncle in a trucking business in Chicago while continuing to pitch at the semi-pro level.

simplicity_issues.explanation: The simplified text changes 'worked with his uncle in a trucking business' to 'worked with his uncle's trucking business,' which implies ownership by the uncle, not just collaboration.
simplicity_issues.suggested_fix: Revise to: 'After retiring, he worked with his uncle in a trucking business in Chicago and continued to play semi-pro baseball.'

simplicity_issues.simplified_span: Grove was the only freshman on his high school baseball team, and his pitching skills caught the attention of the White Sox.
simplicity_issues.explanation: The sentence contains two ideas that could be separated for clarity: Grove being the only freshman and his skills catching the attention of the White Sox.
simplicity_issues.suggested_fix: Grove was the only freshman on his high school baseball team. His pitching skills caught the attention of the White Sox.

simplicity_issues.simplified_span: He signed with them in 1937 and spent a few years going between the major leagues and minor leagues.
simplicity_issues.explanation: The phrase 'going between the major leagues and minor leagues' is somewhat informal and could be clearer.
simplicity_issues.suggested_fix: He signed with them in 1937 and spent a few years alternating between the major leagues and minor leagues.

simplicity_issues.simplified_span: In 1943, he became a steady part of the White Sox's pitching team.
simplicity_issues.explanation: The phrase 'steady part of the White Sox's pitching team' is somewhat vague and could be more specific.
simplicity_issues.suggested_fix: In 1943, he became a regular member of the White Sox's pitching rotation.

simplicity_issues.simplified_span: That year, he performed his best with his lowest ERA, most wins, and most complete games.
simplicity_issues.explanation: The phrase 'performed his best' is informal and could be more precise.
simplicity_issues.suggested_fix: That year, he achieved his best performance with his lowest ERA, most wins, and most complete games.

simplicity_issues.simplified_span: After retiring, he worked with his uncle's trucking business in Chicago and continued to play semi-pro baseball.
simplicity_issues.explanation: The sentence contains two distinct ideas that could be separated for clarity.
simplicity_issues.suggested_fix: After retiring, he worked with his uncle's trucking business in Chicago. He also continued to play semi-pro baseball.

title: Orval Grove
original:
Orval Leroy Grove (August 29, 1919 – April 20, 1992) was an American professional baseball pitcher in Major League Baseball who played for ten seasons in the American League with the Chicago White Sox. In 207 career games, Grove pitched 1,176 innings and posted a win–loss record of 63–73, with 66 complete games, 11 shutouts, and a 3.78 earned run average (ERA).
The only freshman on the Proviso Township High School varsity baseball team, Grove's pitching ability attracted the attention of the White Sox. After signing with the team in 1937, Grove moved between the major leagues and minor leagues for a few seasons until 1943, when he found a solid place in the White Sox's pitching rotation. Grove had a career-year in 1943, finishing the season with career-bests in ERA, wins, and complete games; in 1944, he made his only All-Star appearance.
Grove spent four more full seasons with the White Sox, and after pitching one game in 1949, was sent to the Sacramento Solons of the Pacific Coast League. After playing four seasons with them, he formally retired from professional baseball. After retirement, he worked with his uncle in a trucking business in Chicago while continuing to pitch at the semi-pro level. In 1992, Grove died at the age of 72.
simplified:
Orval Leroy Grove was born on August 29, 1919, and died on April 20, 1992. He was a baseball pitcher who played in Major League Baseball for ten years in the American League, specifically for the Chicago White Sox. He played a total of 207 games, throwing 1,176 innings. Over his career, he won 63 games and lost 73, and he completed 66 games – meaning he finished every game he started. He also had 11 shutouts, where he didn’t allow the other team to score at all. His average earned run allowed was 3.78.

Orval started out as a talented young pitcher in high school, and the Chicago White Sox noticed him when he signed with the team in 1937. For a few years, he moved back and forth between the big leagues and smaller leagues until 1943, when he became a regular pitcher for the White Sox. He had his best year in 1943, setting personal records for ERA, wins, and complete games. In 1944, he was even chosen to play in the All-Star game.

He continued to pitch for the White Sox for four more years, but in 1949, he moved to a team in the Pacific Coast League called the Sacramento Solons. He played there for four more seasons before retiring from professional baseball. After retiring, he worked with his uncle in a trucking business in Chicago and still played baseball in local, semi-professional leagues. He passed away at the age of 72 in 1992.
